answers: Ethiopians [or Abyssinians or Aksumites; prompt on Blacks; prompt on Africans]
parts: Name these towers, which are attached to mosques and used to make the adhan, or call to prayer, five times per day.
This position is held by the man who recites the call to prayer from a mosque's minaret. Bilal ibn Rabah was appointed by Muhammad as the first holder of this position.
Bilal was from this ethnic group. During the Year of the Elephant, Muhammad's birth-year, a king of Yemen from this ethnic group named Abraha unsuccessfully invaded Mecca.

answers: plaster [accept plaster of Paris; accept stucco]
parts: Identify this material. Many Baroque and Rococo ceilings are surrounded by decorative embellishments made of this material.

Jean-Antoine Houdon, who was fond of making plaster casts, made one of the most accurate portraits of this politician. Robert Mills designed a monument to this man that was the tallest building in the world from 1884 to 1889.
Hiram Powers used a pointing machine to create hundreds of plaster copies of a "slave" of this ethnicity, also the ethnicity of ancient sculptors such as Praxiteles.

answers: the Old Gringo [accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, Ambrose Bierce]
parts: Name this character, who is later killed by Colonel Arroyo after he burns Arroyo's deeds to the Miranda hacienda. The Carlos Fuentes novel titled for this character ends with Harriet Winslow "sitting alone and remembering."
The Old Gringo is eventually revealed to be this author of "An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge" who disappeared in Mexico.
Arturo and Ulises search for the missing author Cesaréa Tinajero in Mexico in The Savage Detectives, which was written by this Chilean.
Identify this name for a variety of baseball leagues where legends such as Satchel Paige played because they were not allowed on Major League teams.
During Jim Crow, black performers traveled to nightclubs such as the Uptown Theatre in Philadelphia that were part of this informal set of venues, whose name is a play on the Borscht Belt.
Many Chitlin Circuit venues are included on the Blues Trail in this state. B. B. King and Elvis Presley were born in this state where Medgar Evers was killed.

answers: cAMP (“C-A-M-P”) [or cyclic AMP; or 3',5'-cyclic adenosine monophosphate]
parts: Name this purine nucleoside which builds up in the brain during wakefulness, causing drowsiness, and is flushed away during sleep. This neuromodulator’s receptors are blocked by caffeine.
The inhibition of adenosine receptors by caffeine leads to increased neural activity, triggering the release of this fight-or-flight hormone from namesake glands above the kidneys.

Upon arriving at liver and muscle cells, epinephrine causes the breakdown of glycogen into glucose via a signal transduction pathway that uses this second messenger molecule to activate protein kinase A.

answers: Shiva [or Maheshwara or Shankara or Tripurantaka]
parts: Name this god who destroyed the Tripura, or the three cities. This member of the Hindu trimurti is often known as the god of destruction.
The cities of Tripura were constructed by the sons of one of these materialistic demigods. Often interpreted as demons, they include the Daityas and oppose the daevas.
After destroying Tripura, Shiva is said to have performed a tandava, one of these actions. Shiva is depicted performing this action in his Nataraja aspect.

answers: airplanes [accept more specific types of airplanes like fighter plane or a Curtiss P-40 Warhawk]
a tree [or an apple tree or a willow tree]
parts: Identify these things. Joe Keller tries to blame his business partner for manufacturing faulty parts for these things during World War II in the play All My Sons.
All My Sons is a play by this author of The Crucible.

All My Sons opens with the destruction of one of these things, which had been honoring the memory of Larry after he went missing. Desdemona sings "Her salt tears fell from her, and softened the stones" in a song titled for one of these things in Othello.
Name this French composer of "The Girl with the Flaxen Hair" and Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun.

This orchestral piece by Debussy consists of three "symphonic sketches," the second of which is "Jeux de vagues," (zhuh de va-ge) or "Play of waves." This piece eschews motivic development in favor of colorful sonorities to evoke the interplay of wind, water, and light.
This Debussy piano piece imitates the Javanese gamelan with pentatonic melodies in its first movement, "Pagodes." Its third movement depicts a garden in the rain with flurrying sixteenth notes.

answers: rope [or twine; or cordage; or cord; accept rope bridges]
parts: The Maya who lived in Guatemala’s highlands had access to this material, which was fashioned into blades and swords. The Aztecs made mirrors from highly polished forms of this mineraloid.

These luxury objects were traded by the Maya who lived in the rainforests. Many of these animal products decorate the war bonnets used by Plains Indians tribes, and other types were used to make quill pens.

In the 19th century, the Mayan Yucatan was a profitable exporter of henequen, primarily used to make this good. Structures named for this good such as the Queshuachaca (“kess-wa-CHA-ka”) helped Inca chasquis (“CHOSS-kees”) do their job.

answers: angular momentum [or moment of momentum; or rotational momentum; prompt on momentum; do not accept or prompt on “linear momentum”]
parts: Name this quantity that is equal to the cross product of a particle's position vector and its momentum vector.
Angular momentum is this type of quantity because it transforms like a vector under a proper rotation, but gains a sign flip when transformed by an improper rotation such as reflection.

When transformed by a linear map R, pseudovectors pick up a sign equal to this mathematical operation applied to R. This operation is non-zero for invertible matrices, and Laplace defined this operation as an expansion of minors of smaller matrices.

answers: Elena Ferrante [prompt on Domenico Starnone or Anita Raja with "under what alias were those books published?"]
parts: Identify this social construct whose "nuclear" form was pervasive in postwar America.

Full Surrogacy Now quotes a passage by this author comparing motherhood to being "a lump of food that my children chewed without stopping" from her novel The Days of Abandonment. Ann Goldstein translated this author's The Story of the Lost Child.

Lewis cites the hypocrisy of surrogate mothers being airlifted out of this country following a 2015 earthquake because they were carrying Israeli fetuses. Nine members of this country's royal family were killed in a 2001 shooting.

answers: language-games [prompt on primitive languages; prompt on games; do not accept "private languages"]
parts: Identify these linguistic concepts. The philosopher who created these concepts claimed they were related by "family resemblances" and illustrated their definition with an example involving colored squares.
The concept of language-games originated in Philosophical Investigations, a work written by this philosopher.

Wittgenstein named his Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus in reference to an earlier Tractatus by this philosopher of the Dutch Golden Age. This Jewish philosopher advanced a kind of substance monism in his Ethics.

answers: maesta [or Maesta with Twenty Angels and Nineteen Saints]
Masaccio [or Tommaso di Ser Giovanni di Simone]
parts: This type of depiction of the Virgin Mary seated on a throne holding a baby Christ was popular in early Renaissance art. Duccio's altarpiece of this name was commissioned for the Siena Cathedral.
The shahada is written backwards on Mary's halo in this artist's San Giovenale Triptych. A red angel hovers above Adam and Eve in a painting this artist created for the Brancacci Chapel.

A large Virgin Mary dominates Piero della Francesca's Polyptych of the Misericordia. Piero also wrote an early treatise on the use of the linear type of this technique to create more realistic images.

answers: cement [or hydraulic cement; or opus caementicium; accept concrete or reinforced concrete]
parts: The Bolsheviks formed paramilitary groups of this name to counter the revolutionary Basmachi movement in Turkestan. This name is shared by a faction of the Creeks that killed some 500 people at Fort Mims in 1813.
Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan were important Soviet sources of this resource. In the 1960s, the Soviets built the Druzhba pipeline to transport this fuel to East Germany.

Soviet-era Dushanbe was the site of a large factory to make this good. The recipe for the Roman "underwater" form of this good was lost for centuries. These days, it's often combined with aggregates such as sand.

answers: Jean Rhys (“jeen reese”) [or Ella Gwendolyn Rees Williams]
parts: Name this author whose best-known novel describes how Antoinette Cosway’s mother is driven insane by the burning of Coulibri plantation.
Antoinette Cosway is called the “madwoman in the attic” in this Charlotte Brontë novel, the jumping off point for Rhys’s Wide Sargasso Sea. Mr. Rochester owns Thornfield Hall in this novel.

Antoinette accidentally starts a fire after she is startled by passing one of these objects at the end of Wide Sargasso Sea. One of these objects is damaged after the line “out flew the web and floated wide” in “The Lady of Shalott.”

answers: N95 respirator [or N95s; or N95 filtering facepiece respirator; prompt on respirators, face masks or mechanical filters; do not accept or prompt on “KN95”]
PM10 OR PM2.5 [accept 10 microns OR 2.5 microns; prompt on coarse or fine particulate matter]
parts: Name these objects. Peter Tsai patented the use of electrostatic materials in these objects to promote interception and impaction, and un-retired to investigate their response to steam and dry heat.
N95s must retain at least 95 percent of airborne particulates in these two categories, named for their maximum diameter in microns. Name either category of particulates.
As mechanical respirators, N95s allow molecules in this phase through, meaning that one should have no trouble breathing in a mask.

answers: ciphers [or codes; accept answers like secret messages]
parts: The Elzevirs made their fortune selling these items. William Caxton was the first to make one type of these items in England.

The Elzevirs published Opera Mathematica, a treatise by François Viète (“vee-ET”), who worked on these things under two French kings. Leon Battista Alberti developed a tool composed of two concentric circles for creating these things.
Despite censorship from the Inquisition, the Elzevirs published Two New Sciences, a book by this Italian astronomer of Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems.
Name this poet whose most famous works are collected in “Pythian,” “Isthmian,” and “Nemean” books of poetry.
Another of Pindar’s four books of victory odes concerns these games held every four years in honor of Zeus.

This later poet drew on Pindar’s style for an elegy in honor of the Egyptian queen Berenice’s chariot racing prowess in his Aetia. Stephanie Burt made Tumblr references in a 2020 book about this mentor of Apollonius of Rhodes who indexed the Library of Alexandria in his now-lost Pinakes.

answers: d-sub-(x² − y²) orbital [accept x-squared minus y-squared]
parts: Name these metallic elements in the middle of the periodic table that have partially filled d orbitals.

For coordination complexes with this geometry, CFT predicts that the d orbitals will be split into four energy levels, with the d-sub-xz and d-sub-yz orbitals having the lowest energy. This geometry has a central atom connected to four others, with 90 degrees between each bond.
For a square planar complex, this d orbital is the highest energy because its density lies directly on the axes of the xy-plane.

answers: mandatory arbitration [or binding arbitration; prompt on alternative dispute resolution or ADR or dispute resolution or reaching a settlement; do not accept or prompt on “mediation”]
healthcare industry [or medical industry; or doctors; or hospitals; or pharmacies; accept Electronic Medical Records; prompt on insurance industry]
parts: Name this alternative to jury trials, increasingly used by companies to prevent lawsuits.

In May 2018, the Supreme Court found that Epic Systems, a company that provides software for this industry, could use arbitration to ban class action suits. Epic has benefited from a 2016 “21st Century” Act that has provided federal funding for digitizing this industry.
This ride-sharing company founded by Travis Kalanick had at least 60,000 arbitration claims against it when it went public in 2019.

answers: compass [or pair of compasses; prompt on tool]
J. M. W. Turner [or Joseph Mallord William Turner]
parts: Name these objects. Blake also depicted a nude man in profile sitting hunched over on an algae-covered rock, holding one of these objects to a piece of paper on the ground.
That second print by Blake depicts this English physicist who co-discovered calculus.
This avid watercolorist referenced Goethe's rivaling theory of color in a work of "The Morning after the Deluge." John Ruskin championed this painter, who names a prize awarded by the Tate.
